conclusion: The problem involves determining the distance between the position where red light hits a screen and point A, using properties of a semicircular brick and a right triangle.

Given information includes refractive index of the brick (√3), speed of light in vacuum (C), angle between incident direction and BC (60 degrees), and angle between incident and refracted light (30 degrees).
The screen MN is perpendicular to the horizontal plane, and the beam of red light is directed at the center O of the semicircular brick.
The refracted angle ∠OBD is given as 30 degrees.
Using the refractive index (√3), ∠OBD is calculated as 60 degrees using τan(∠OBD) = √3.
The distance AB is the hypotenuse of the right triangle ABC.
Using the Pythagorean theorem, AB is expressed as √(BC^2 + AB^2).
Using properties of a 30-60-90 triangle, AB is calculated as (2/√3) × BC.
Using properties of a 60-60-60 triangle, BC is calculated as (2/√3) × AB.
Substituting AB into the equation for BC, BC is expressed as (2/√3) × √(BC^2 + AB^2).
Further simplifications are attempted to calculate BC, but the process becomes overly repetitive and unclear.
